title_sort: walter whitman reynolds to walt whitman, 26 april 1870
title: Walter Whitman Reynolds to Walt Whitman, 26 April 1870
text: April 26 1870My Dear friend WaltI now take my pen in hand to let you know how I am getting along . I am in very good health at present and I hope you are the same. my father is not very well at present he has been Laid up for a week with the Rhumatism[Rheumatism]. In his feet he is getting Better. I am very sorry to have any bad news to tell you but I can not help it. I have got in trouble I bought some potent medicine to the amount of three Dollars. I bought some medicine for a friend of my fathers & he gave me the money to pay for them & I Spent it I am very sorry I Done it. I have Learnt a lesson from it witchwhich will last me a life time. We have a new basher's & he is looking over the books & he seen the account against me & he says if I Do not pay it before Saturday night he will tell Robbins & then I will be Disgraced & DiscargedDischarged I asked my Sister to lend three Dollars & she would not. She said I might get Discraseddisgraced for all She cared & now I apply to you the last friend I have in this world I wish you would lend three Dollars & I will pay you as soon as I can earn it you will oblidge me very much & save me from being Disgraced. this is all at present, I will write as soon as I hear from youand now good bybye fromyour friend with loveWalt Whitman RI will put this in an & try Envelope so that if you Do not Receive it I will get it without any one seeing it.yours &c. WR Walter Whitman Reynolds to Walt Whitman, 26 April 1870
